data: [{"id":"doi_dedup___::12090d709314a1a92cbc9d48ebf7198d","subject":"Medicine","title":"The diet of a nocturnal pelagic predator, the Bulwer\u2019s petrel, across the lunar cycle","year":"2017-05-03","publisher":"Nature Portfolio","resulttype":"publication","language":"","published_in":"Scientific Reports","link":"http:\/\/europepmc.org\/articles\/PMC5431196","fulltext":"","paper_abstract":"Existe informa\u00e7\u00e3o suplementar dispon\u00edvel na vers\u00e3o online. The lunar cycle is believed to strongly influence the vertical distribution of many oceanic taxa, with implications for the foraging behaviour of nocturnal marine predators. Most studies to date testing lunar effects on foraging have focused on predator activity at-sea, with some birds and marine mammals demonstrating contrasting behavioural patterns, depending on the lunar-phase. However, to date no study has focused on how the lunar cycle might actually affect predator-prey interactions in the upper layers of the ocean. Here, we tested whether the diet of the predominantly nocturnal pelagic predator, the Bulwer's petrel (Bulweria bulwerii) would change throughout the lunar cycle, using molecular analysis to augment detection and taxonomic resolution of prey collected from stomach-contents. We found no evidence of dietary shifts in species composition or diversity, with Bulwer's petrel always consuming a wide range of mesopelagic species. Other co-variables potentially affecting light availability at-sea, such as percentage of cloud cover, did not confound our results. Moreover, many of the species found are thought not to reach the sea-surface. Our findings reveal that nocturnal predators are probably more specialized than previously assumed, irrespective of ambient-light, but also reveal deficiencies in our current understanding of species vertical distribution and predation-dynamics at-sea. Funda\u00e7\u00e3o para a Ci\u00eancia e a Tecnologia (FCT); FEDER info:eu-repo\/semantics\/publishedVersion","doi":"10.1038\/s41598-017-01312-3","project_id":"SFRH\/BD\/73656\/2010","accessright":"Open Access","authors":"S. Waap; S. Waap; Maria P. Dias; Maria P. Dias; Catarina Serra-Gon\u00e7alves; William Oliver Christian Symondson; Jos\u00e9 Pedro Granadeiro; Hany Alonso; Hany Alonso; Paulo Catry","subject_orig":"Medicine","oa_state":1,"url":"doi_dedup___::12090d709314a1a92cbc9d48ebf7198d","cluster_labels":"Medicine","x":"0.0329710664269243","y":"0.341728937888148","labels":"doi_dedup___::12090d709314a1a92cbc9d48ebf7198d","area_uri":3,"area":"Medicine"},{"id":"doi_dedup___::15560b4a471cfcce4896bc0cdd16080e","subject":"Pterodroma","title":"Gadfly petrels use knowledge of the windscape, not memorized foraging patches, to optimize foraging trips on ocean-wide scales.","year":"2020-01-15","publisher":"The Royal Society","resulttype":"publication","language":"","published_in":"Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences","link":"http:\/\/ora.ox.ac.uk\/objects\/uuid:","fulltext":"","paper_abstract":"<jats:p> Seabirds must often travel vast distances to exploit heterogeneously distributed oceanic resources, but how routes and destinations of foraging trips are optimized remains poorly understood. Among the seabirds, gadfly petrels ( <jats:italic>Pterodroma<\/jats:italic> spp.) are supremely adapted for making efficient use of wind energy in dynamic soaring flight. We used GPS tracking data to investigate the role of wind in the flight behaviour and foraging strategy of the Desertas petrel, <jats:italic>Pterodroma deserta<\/jats:italic> . We found that rather than visiting foraging hotspots, Desertas petrels maximize prey encounter by covering some of the longest distances known in any animal in a single foraging trip (up to 12 000 km) over deep, pelagic waters. Petrels flew with consistent crosswind (relative wind angle 60\u00b0), close to that which maximizes their groundspeed. By combining state\u2013space modelling with a series of comparisons to simulated foraging trips (reshuffled-random, rotated, time-shifted, reversed), we show that this resulted in trajectories that were close to the fastest possible, given the location and time. This wind use is thus consistent both with birds using current winds to fine-tune their routes and, impressively, with an <jats:italic>a priori<\/jats:italic> knowledge of predictable regional-scale wind regimes, facilitating efficient flight over great distances before returning to the home colony. <\/jats:p>","doi":"10.1098\/rspb.2019.1775","project_id":"PTDC\/MAR-PRO\/0929\/2014","accessright":"Open Access","authors":"Francesco Ventura; Jos\u00e9 Pedro Granadeiro; Oliver Padget; Paulo Catry","subject_orig":"Pterodroma","oa_state":1,"url":"doi_dedup___::15560b4a471cfcce4896bc0cdd16080e","cluster_labels":"Memorized foraging patches, Optimize foraging trips, Gadfly petrels","x":"-0.492240867582751","y":"-0.0548653479371893","labels":"doi_dedup___::15560b4a471cfcce4896bc0cdd16080e","area_uri":1,"area":"Memorized foraging patches, Optimize foraging trips, Gadfly petrels"},{"id":"doi_dedup___::3291e201a4952df5986f5fe5a9111297","subject":"foraging patches; foraging trips; gadfly petrels","title":"Supporting information on the available data and the statistical analysis from Gadfly petrels use knowledge of the windscape, not memorized foraging patches, to optimize foraging trips on ocean-wide scales","year":"2019-01-01","publisher":"The Royal Society","resulttype":"publication","language":"","published_in":"","link":"https:\/\/doi.org\/10.6084\/m9.figshare.11407062","fulltext":"","paper_abstract":"Additional information on (1) the available data; (2) the spatial analysis; (3) the energy model","doi":"10.6084\/m9.figshare.11407062","project_id":"PTDC\/MAR-PRO\/0929\/2014","accessright":"Open Access","authors":"Ventura, Francesco; Granadeiro, Jos\u00e9 Pedro; Padget, Oliver; Catry, Paulo","subject_orig":"","oa_state":1,"url":"doi_dedup___::3291e201a4952df5986f5fe5a9111297","cluster_labels":"Memorized foraging patches, Optimize foraging trips, Gadfly petrels","x":"0.470059467269915","y":"-0.0860338377749894","labels":"doi_dedup___::3291e201a4952df5986f5fe5a9111297","area_uri":1,"area":"Memorized foraging patches, Optimize foraging trips, Gadfly petrels"},{"id":"od______2292::82dd7201eb2dacbbd6325f24c12c5264","subject":"Habitat","title":"Consequ\u00eancias das escolhas migrat\u00f3rias e da acumula\u00e7\u00e3o de merc\u00fario nas cagarras","year":"2017-01-01","publisher":"Universidade de Aveiro","resulttype":"publication","language":"","published_in":"","link":"http:\/\/hdl.handle.net\/10773\/21965","fulltext":"","paper_abstract":"Mestrado em Biologia Marinha The migratory decisions of Cory\u2019s shearwaters (Calonectris borealis) potentially have an impact on individuals, producing carry-over effects, with implications for population structure and dynamics. The main goals in this study were to compare the distribution of a studied population of Cory\u2019s Shearwaters, at Selvagem Grande, during the non-breeding period; investigate the influence of wintering ground on the date of arrival at the colony and body condition on arrival and how these factors could relate with reproductive success and see how these previously mentioned factors were influenced by mercury (Hg) accumulation in the wintering ground and how this contaminant was distributed amongst wintering locations. Most of the studied individuals migrated to oceanic regions around southern Africa. Individuals wintering in the Canary Current were all males and the first to return to breeding grounds. Relative to reproduction, overall laying and hatching success were high and close to values recorded for other seabirds. Females handled in March had a higher percentage of egg presence in the respective nest when compared to males. Laying success did not increase with early arrival dates. Males having wintered in the Canary Current had a laying success of 57.9% and those wintering in southern Africa 75.4%. Body condition did not have any relationship with reproduction and arrival date, but it seemed slightly lower for male individuals wintering in Canary Current, in comparison with the other males. The mean mercury concentration deposited in winter grown flight feathers of adult Cory\u2019s Shearwaters was 5.80 \u00b1 2.3 mg\/kg, with no difference between males and females. Males wintering in the Canary current registered the lowest mercury burden when compared with birds spending the winter in southern Africa locations. Mercury concentrations due to the exposure in wintering grounds did not seem to affect the duration of migration, laying success neither body condition amongst individuals. However, there was a positive correlation between arrival dates from southern Africa males and mercury concentrations, in which individuals arriving later had higher mercury concentrations. It was possible to assess a certain influence and carry-over effects from wintering locations in these individuals\u2019 traits. The collected data provides information about this species distribution and influences of its distribution in its life choices, which can be used to conservation measures. Also, using this species as a biomonitor for environmental mercury provides important insights about its levels in wintering areas. As escolhas migrat\u00f3rias das Cagarras (Calonectris borealis) t\u00eam um potencial impacto nos indiv\u00edduos, podendo produzir efeitos \u201ccarry-over\u201d com implica\u00e7\u00f5es na estrutura e din\u00e2mica populacional. Os principais objetivos deste estudo foram: comparar a distribui\u00e7\u00e3o de uma popula\u00e7\u00e3o estudada de cagarras da Selvagem Grande durante o per\u00edodo n\u00e3o reprodutor; investigar se o local de invernada teve algum tipo de influ\u00eancia na data de retorno \u00e0 col\u00f3nia, na dura\u00e7\u00e3o da migra\u00e7\u00e3o, condi\u00e7\u00e3o corporal e sucesso reprodutor; observar como estes fatores se relacionam com a acumula\u00e7\u00e3o de merc\u00fario (Hg) nos indiv\u00edduos no local de invernada; e averiguar a distribui\u00e7\u00e3o deste contaminante na esp\u00e9cie em estudo. A maioria dos indiv\u00edduos migrou para regi\u00f5es oce\u00e2nicas em torno do sul de \u00c1frica. Os indiv\u00edduos que invernaram na Corrente das Can\u00e1rias eram todos machos e os primeiros a retornar \u00e0 col\u00f3nia na Selvagem Grande. Relativamente ao sucesso reprodutivo, o sucesso na coloca\u00e7\u00e3o e eclos\u00e3o do ovo foi elevado e semelhante a valores registados em estudos anteriores para outras aves marinhas. As f\u00eameas amostradas em mar\u00e7o tiveram uma maior percentagem de ovo no ninho do que os machos. O sucesso na coloca\u00e7\u00e3o de um ovo n\u00e3o aumentou com a anteced\u00eancia na chegada. Os machos da corrente das Can\u00e1rias tiveram uma taxa de sucesso de coloca\u00e7\u00e3o de ovo de 57.9% e os da regi\u00e3o sul Africana 75.4%. N\u00e3o se verificou qualquer rela\u00e7\u00e3o entre condi\u00e7\u00e3o corporal e reprodu\u00e7\u00e3o e entre condi\u00e7\u00e3o corporal e data de chegada, apesar de os machos da corrente das Can\u00e1rias terem registado valores um pouco mais reduzidos. A concentra\u00e7\u00e3o m\u00e9dia de merc\u00fario acumulada em penas que cresceram durante o per\u00edodo de invernada das cagarras foi de 5,8\u00b12,3 mg\/kg, sem se terem registado diferen\u00e7as entre machos e f\u00eameas. Os machos que invernaram na corrente das Can\u00e1rias registaram os n\u00edveis mais baixos de merc\u00fario comparando com os da regi\u00e3o sul Africana. As concentra\u00e7\u00f5es de merc\u00fario derivadas da exposi\u00e7\u00e3o nos locais de invernada n\u00e3o afetaram os n\u00edveis de sucesso na coloca\u00e7\u00e3o de ovo, nem a dura\u00e7\u00e3o da migra\u00e7\u00e3o, nem a condi\u00e7\u00e3o corporal entre os indiv\u00edduos. No entanto, registou-se uma fraca correla\u00e7\u00e3o positiva entre datas de chegada dos machos da regi\u00e3o sul Africana e concentra\u00e7\u00f5es de merc\u00fario, na qual os indiv\u00edduos que chegaram mais tarde tinham n\u00edveis mais baixos de merc\u00fario. Foi, portanto, poss\u00edvel observar um certo n\u00edvel de influ\u00eancia das escolhas migrat\u00f3rias e tamb\u00e9m efeitos \u201ccarry-over\u201d quer ao n\u00edvel da escolha do local de invernada, quer ao n\u00edvel de concentra\u00e7\u00f5es de merc\u00fario nestes indiv\u00edduos. Os dados obtidos fornecem informa\u00e7\u00e3o acerca da distribui\u00e7\u00e3o da esp\u00e9cie e influencia das suas escolhas migrat\u00f3rias, o que pode ser usado para medidas de conserva\u00e7\u00e3o. A utiliza\u00e7\u00e3o da esp\u00e9cie como biomonitor de n\u00edveis de merc\u00fario \u00e9 tamb\u00e9m um meio de obter informa\u00e7\u00e3o sobre os n\u00edveis deste contaminante no ambiente aqu\u00e1tico, terrestre e na atmosfera.","doi":"","project_id":"UID\/MAR\/04292\/2013","accessright":"Open Access","authors":"Reis, Bianca Raquel Correia dos","subject_orig":"Aves marinhas - Habitat","oa_state":1,"url":"od______2292::82dd7201eb2dacbbd6325f24c12c5264","cluster_labels":"Habitat","x":"-0.0107896661140888","y":"-0.200829752175969","labels":"od______2292::82dd7201eb2dacbbd6325f24c12c5264","area_uri":2,"area":"Habitat"}]
